Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding the applicant did not meet the burden of proof regarding state protection and Convention grounds for refugee status
Application_Facts: Kwasi Danquah claimed persecution by his uncle and NDC officials after leaving the party; reported an attack to police but could not identify assailants; documentary evidence showed Ghana’s efforts to reform its police force despite issues
Decision_Outcome: Board reasonably concluded applicant failed to rebut presumption of state protection and did not establish nexus to Convention grounds
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division's decision
Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking refugee status in Canada
Legal_Standard: Presumption of state protection unless claimant provides clear evidence of state's inability or unwillingness to protect; refugee status requires well-founded fear of persecution linked to Convention grounds
Assessment_Factor: Credibility of claim, availability and effectiveness of state protection, nexus to Convention grounds
Credibility_Assessment: Claimant could not identify attackers, limiting police action; insufficient evidence of state incapacity or unwillingness
Evidence_Used: Claimant's testimony, documentary evidence on Ghana’s police reforms
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution based on political opinion and family conflict
Evidence_Assessed: Police response to attack report, systemic capacity of Ghanaian state to provide protection
Governing_Rule: Presumption of state protection; need to show well-founded fear tied to Convention grounds
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide clear evidence that state was unable or unwilling to protect
Harm_Assessment: Alleged attack and fear of future persecution by political actors and family members
Cause_Description: Applicant sought refugee status in Canada, claiming persecution in Ghana due to political activities
Evidence_Handling: Board assessed credibility and sufficiency of evidence regarding state protection
Evidence_Issues: Lack of identification of attackers weakened claim; insufficient proof of state complicity or incapacity
Evidence_Assessment: Documentary evidence acknowledged police reform efforts in Ghana; claimant's evidence deemed insufficient to overcome presumption of state protection
Decision_Rationale: Applicant did not rebut presumption of state protection or demonstrate nexus to Convention grounds
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient evidence to prove state inability or unwillingness to protect; lack of specific details about perpetrators
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds; burden of proof on claimant
